Ideas to implement NFR 58 (protect ePHI from improper alteration/destruction):
- Add integrity controls: database-level constraints, row versioning/timestamps, soft-deletes with restore, and audit trails for writes (who/what changed).
- Implement tamper-evident logging: append-only audit logs with integrity checks (e.g., cryptographic hash chaining, WORM storage).
- Add field-level validation and business rules to prevent improper edits; require dual-authorization for sensitive changes.
- Provide backup/restore and point-in-time recovery to undo destructive changes.
- Introduce immutability for critical records after sign-off (e.g., locked finalized visit notes).
- Add monitoring alerts on unusual write/delete patterns and periodic integrity checks (checksums).
019d48a7-0732-46d0-9c28-19d49c578a2a.user_message: How can this NFR 58 be implemented?

What’s missing for NFR 58 is deeper integrity coverage: no row/version snapshots of the before/after data, no soft-deletes/restore, and no tamper-evident logs—so you can see an edit happened, but you can’t verify or roll back improper alterations.
